qas.question: What Newtonian concept can be used in the formulation of an idea for the synchronization of clocks?

answers.text: concept of "relative, apparent, and common time"

qas.question: In which century did physicists encounter problems with the understanding of time?
The behavior of which two phenomena caused physicists to encounter problems with their understanding of time in the late 19th century?

answers.text: the behavior of electricity and magnetism

qas.question: Which famous scientist resolved these issues?
In what year did Einstein encounter problems with using electricity?
Who's concept can be used to synchronize the use of electricity?

plausible_answers.text: the constant, finite speed of light as the maximum signal velocity

qas.question: What did physicists use to solve the problems of electricity synchronization?

plausible_answers.text: observers in motion relative to one another measure different elapsed times for the same event

qas.question: What did the use of the speed of light by Newton lead to?
What concept by Einstein can be used to synchronize electricity in classical mechanics?

plausible_answers.text: concept of "relative, apparent, and common time

qas.question: What Newtonian concept can be used in the formulation of an idea for the understanding of clocks?
In which century did physicists encounter problems with the understanding of electricity?
Which famous scientist struggled with these issues?

plausible_answers.text: the behavior of electricity and magnetism

qas.question: The behavior of which two phenomena caused physicists to encounter problems with their understanding of clocks in the late 19th century?

plausible_answers.text: by invoking a method of synchronizing clocks

qas.question: How did Einstein resolve the two different observers?

context: In non-relativistic classical mechanics, <b5_0>Newton's<b5_0/> <a0_0><b9_0>concept of <b8_0>"relative, apparent, and common time<b9_0/>"<b8_0/><a0_0/> can be used in the formulation of a prescription for the synchronization of clocks. Events seen by two different observers in motion relative to each other produce a mathematical concept of time that works sufficiently well for describing the everyday phenomena of most people's experience. <b4_0>In <a1_0><b10_0>the late nineteenth century<b10_0/><b4_0/><a1_0/>, physicists encountered problems with the classical understanding of time, in connection with <a2_0><b12_0>the behavior of electricity and magnetism<b12_0/><a2_0/>. <a3_0><b11_0>Einstein<b11_0/><a3_0/> resolved these problems <b13_0>by invoking a method of synchronizing clocks<b13_0/> using <b6_0>the constant, finite speed of light as the maximum signal velocity<b6_0/>. This led directly to the result that <b7_0>observers in motion relative to one another measure different elapsed times for the same event<b7_0/>.
